Starting from the Baltimore Association of Com-
merce, 22 LIGHT STREET ®, proceed south on
LIGHT ST., passing wharves, and turn left on
HUGHES ST. to Federal Hill @©. From here, take
KEY HIGHWAY route to FORT AVENUE, and
turn left to Fort McHenry @. Return on FORT
AVENUE to HANOVER ST., turn right to LOM-
‘BARD ST., turn left to GREENE STREET @&,
turn right to FAYETTE ST. @, turn right to
HOWARD ST., turn left ® to MULBERRY ST.,
turn right to CATHEDRAL ST., turn left @ to
CENTRE ST., turn right to CALVERT ST., and
turn right again to FAYETTE ST. ®.
Turn left on FAYETTE ST., passing the Civic
Center ® and the Shot Tower @. Immediately
after passing the Shot Tower, turn right on HIGH
ST. to PRATT ST., turn right one block to the
Flag House @ at ALBEMARLE ST., then turn
right again to BALTIMORE ST. Turn right on :
BALTIMORE ST. to BROADWAY, then turn left,
- passing the group of Johns Hopkins Hospital
buildings @, and continue to HARFORD ROAD.
Turn right on HARFORD RD. ® to ALAMEDA
BLVD., and then left to 33RD ST. @. Turn left
again on 33RD ST. ®, passing the Municipal
Stadium @©), to UNIVERSITY PKWY.
Tuarn right on UNIVERSITY PKWY. to GREEN.-
WAY and turn right on GREENWAY through
Guilford to CHARLES ST. AVE. Bear right on
CHARLES ST. AVE. @ ® to BELVEDERE AVE.,
then turn left on BELVEDERE to ROLAND AVE.
Turn left @ €) on ROLAND AVE. through Roland
Park and bear left into UNIVERSITY PKWY. to
N. CHARLES ST.

sl POINTS OF INTEREST




1. FEDERAL HILL—Hughes St., Battery and Warren Aves.
Commanding an excellent view of Baltimore’s upper harbor
and skyline, this site was fortified by Union forces during the
Civil War.

2. FORT McHENRY—This National Park is a vivid reminder
of our defense against the British fleet in September, 1814,
which inspired Francis Scott Key to compose our national
anthem.

3. UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND & UNIVERSITY HOSPITAL—
Greene and Lombard Sts. Founded in 1807, the University
includes the oldest dental college in the world.

4. POE’S GRAVE & WESTMINISTER CHURCH—Fayette &
Greene Sts. The grave of Edgar Allan Poe, who died in
Baltimore in 1849, is in the northwest corner of this old





Bih iy =

BALTIMORE USBUM
or ART

<


















outstanding example of school

architecture

: -~ &







NV
OWN IIYD

ivy-covered graveyard.
& # 5. RETAIL SHOPPING DISTRICT—Most of the large depart-
e 4 Q ment stores of the city are located in this area.
; ? 6. ENOCH PRATT FREE LIBRARY—Cathedral Street between
‘Q Franklin and Mulberry Streets. (Open daily 9 A.M. to 9 P.M.;
Reference Room open Sundays and Holidays 2 to 9 P.M.) One

of the finest of public libraries, with nearly 700,000 volumes
in central building and 26 branches. The Maryland Room

. . contains early records of the province and a large collection

» x lfmmﬁ.specza@’ {éa)‘e in z& er S]’\,om ’ First Roman Catholic Cathedral in the United States. Corner-

OUCHER COLLEGEK

stone was laid in 1806 by Bishop Carroll, who later became
the first Archbishop in the United States. He is buried in
the crypt, as is also James Cardinal Gibbons, the first American

Cardinal.
A, 8. BATTLE MONUMENT—Calvert and Fayette Sts. Commem-
: orates the Battle of North Point. It was this heroic defense
: in 1814 that made Balitimore the only large city on the

Atlantic seaboard free from invasion by the foe.

oS e













i























;_l]] 9. BALTIMORE CIVIC CENTER——Comprises the Court House,
Post Office, City Hall, Municipal Office Building, Memorial
Plaza and the War Memorial.

10. SHOT TOWER—TFayette and Front Sts. Built in 1828
the Shot Tower is a massive shaft of brick 234 feet high.
Shot was made by dropping hot lead down the shaft into tanks









of cooling water. Few such towers are still standing.

11. FLAG HOUSE—Pratt and Albemarle Sts. (Open 10 A.M.
to 5 P.M. daily except Sunday.) In this old-fashioned house
Mary Pickersgill made the American Flag that waved over
Fort McHenry during the bombardment by the British in 1814.
12. JOHNS HOPKINS HOSPITAL & MEDICAL SCHOOL—
Broadway, Monument and Wolfe Streets. Endowed in 1876
with a bequest of $7,000,000 by its namesake, the Johns
Hopkins Hospital and Medical School is a group of 25 build-









MONUMENT
















! f'.o'
il













ings covering twelve city blocks. It is famous throughout the





T

paiciraL BUILDING (i













world for its leading contributions to many branches of
medical science.

13. CLIFTON PARK—TFormerly the estate of Johns Hopkins.

]





















































































"Z S His country residence was the Mansion House in the park.
© Present facilities provide for baseball, football, golf, soccer,
ﬁ swimming, tennis, etc.
Ko E 14. CITY COLLEGE—E. 33rd Sireet and Alameda. This
i E publie high school for boys, founded over a century ago,
> is now housed in a beautiful modern building.
" 15. EASTERN HIGH SCHOOL—E. 33rd Street. One of Balti-
2 and Saratoga ! more’s outstanding high schools for girls.
; \'l‘ Strccts 5 16. MUNICIPAL STADIUM—E. 33rd Street. One of the
gl largest municipal arenas in the couniry, seating 70,000; tem-
& porary home of Baltimore Orioles baseball team and scene
o of important football games.
17. LOYOLA COLLEGE—Charles St. Ave. and Cold Spring
R . Lane. Catholic college for men.
toger At 18. NOTRE DAME OF MARYLAND—Charles St. Ave. High

EDGAR ALLAN PO . y | ] 3 = : for boys in America. Founded in 1897.
21. JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY—Charles and 34th Streets.





The campus includes all buildings of the University except
those of the Hygiene and Public Health and Medical Schools.
Also on the campus is the Homewood House, with its exquisite
interiors, built in 1803 as a wedding present from Charles
Carroll of Carrollton, one of the signers of the Declaration of
Independence, to his son, Charles Carroll IV. i

22. BALTIMORE MUSEUM OF ART—Wyman Park off Charles
Street. (Open Tuesday to Saturday 11 A.M. to 6 P.M., Sunday
2 to 6 P.M.) This museum provides Baltimore with many fine
transient and permanent exhibits.

23. DRUID HILL PARK—One of the largest natural parks
within the corporate limits of any ecity. First used by the
city in 1860, its 674 acres provide many lovely vistas of
natural beauty. Modern recreational facilities include swim-
ming pools, playgrounds, tennis courts, playing field and a

ool : fearing a catastrophe were the monument to topple over.

. o . Today the ‘“‘country’ site is a city landmark and the monu-
ment is still standing.
26. PEABODY INSTITUTE AND LIBRARY—1 E. Mi. Vernon
. Place (Latter open daily except Sunday 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.)
> It is one of the leading conservatories of music in the
country, and was given to the City by George Peabody.
27. WALTERS ART GALLERY—Charles Street at Centre.
i (Open daily 11 A. M. to 5 P.M., Sundays 2 P.M. to 5 P.M.)
Here is one of the largest art collections, privately owned,
i in the world, including the original manuseript of the “Star

o 3 artistic history of all important civilizations. It was bequeathed
to the city by the late Henry Walters in 1939.
